name: Representing disasters
description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

key_work.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
key_work.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

start.title: The Perfect Storm
start.creator_credit: Baltimore Spring Creek Productions, Radiant Productions, Warner Bros. Pictures, Wolfgang Petersen, William Sandell, Erica Edell Phillips, William D. Wittliff, Paula Weinstein and Gail Katz
start.brief_description: In October 1991, a confluence of weather conditions combined to form a killer storm in the North Atlantic. Caught in the storm was the sword-fishing boat Andrea Gail. Magnificent foreshadowing and anticipation fill this true-life drama while minute details of the fishing boats, their gear and the weather are juxtaposed with the sea adventure.

links.description: Also based on the true story of a natural disaster that had tragic consequences, The Perfect Storm (2000) broke ground with its VFX of the gigantic wave that eventually dooms the crew. Weta’s Christopher White worked on that sequence, along with the tornados from Twister (1996).
